docs.lead_paragraph: The justices appeared receptive to arguments that the court could hear the case now, suggesting they will reject the argument made by an outside lawyer that it is too soon to rule.

headline.seo: Health Law Hearings Open in Supreme Court
headline.main: Justices Hear Argument That Health Case Is Premature
headline.print_headline: Three Days of Hearings on Health Law Begin Before the Supreme Court

docs.abstract: Supreme Court appears ready to clear away the last remaining obstacle to a historic ruling on President Obama’s health care overhaul; at the opening of three days of arguments, the justices’ questions suggested that they are receptive to a point on which both supporters and opponents of the law agree: that the court should decide the case now rather than waiting until the law’s penalties for not having health insurance become due.
docs.snippet: The justices appeared receptive to arguments that the court could hear the case now, suggesting they will reject the argument made by an outside lawyer that it is too soon to rule.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a senior citizen circuit battle over Medicare, Republicans have Pat Boone, while Democrats have President Bartlett. Last week, the conservative 60Plus Association began running an advertisement against vulnerable Democratic senators featuring Mr. Boone, the aging crooner, with the somewhat convoluted message that President Obama and Democrats are cutting Medicare spending and rationing care, while ignoring the problem of the program going bankrupt.
docs.abstract: Caucus column; aging crooner Pat Boone attacks President Obama for wasteful Medicare spending in ad sponsored by the conservative 60Plus Association; Democrats counter with message by actor Martin Sheen, who criticizes Republicans for plan to end Medicare in their proposed budget. docs.lead_paragraph: No Twitter posts, phone calls or laptops will be allowed during Supreme Court arguments over the constitutionality of President Obama’s health care law.

headline.seo: Supreme Court Goes Predigital for Health Law Arguments
headline.main: Neither Phones, Nor Cameras, Nor Tweets in the Court
headline.print_headline: Neither Phones, Nor Cameras, Nor Tweets in the Court

docs.abstract: Washington Memo; select group of journalists allowed to observe the Supreme Court's arguments over the constitutionality of Pres Obama's health care law will be barred from using technology to communicate during the proceedings, including cell phones and Twitter messages; restrictions are likely to frustrate observers who have become accustomed to watching major news events unfold in real time.
docs.snippet: No Twitter posts, phone calls or laptops will be allowed during Supreme Court arguments over the constitutionality of President Obama’s health care law.
